Author: Timo#5756
Content:
I bet high money here, so I gonna make sure the data comes from big Chainlink node operator. The will be further metrics where I can chose oracles from. I'm not sure how familiar you are with Chainlink...
You CAN have a metric saying, I want to use one node operator that has worked 50.000 jobs and had no penalty/bad data for x amount ot time. I can also go an chose a node operator that is certified by a third party, let's say a known data provider from the non-crypto space. This is gonna be a thing.

Do you think you can pay him enough that he throws away all his reputaiton, losing his revenue he worked for months/years? Let's say you find out which 10 nodes are serving the smart contract and contact them. You would have to convince 50% of them to try and attack the network, sending false data. So either change the data after receiving it from the API, so inside the oracle node, and then  send it (which isn't possible with TEE), or you would have to convince 50% of the actual data provider, the size of bloomberg, which is true as I, who opens the bet with you choose 10 big fucking providers to deliver that data. And the 50% corrupt providers still have the risk in loosing all their stake

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: ok, ignore the game theory if you want. I am just relaying the points made by experts who are deep into this for years

Author: Timo#5756
Content:
"if I have an army of sybil accounts, I cant have them all behave perfectly nicely until I want to corrupt some oracle data?"
An army of sybil accounts don't mean anything, they would be outweighted by a lot. You have for example someone with 100.000$ of Chainlink token. That is just one of ten. So you pay atleast 1 million in acuiring the token for only having more stake. Then you have the reputaiton. If you just newly created these accounts, the reputation is pretty much zero. So no matter if you got 500.000$ of LINK tokens int total of these 5 nodes, they will get outweighted after the reputation get's calculated in

Content: ./komodod -ac_cbopret=7 -ac_prices="LTC, BCHABC, XMR, IOTA, ZEC, WAVES, LSK, DCR, RVN, DASH, XEM, BTS, ICX, HOT, STEEM, ENJ, STRAT" -pubkey=<yourpubkey> -ac_name=REKT0 -ac_cclib=prices -ac_cc=10777 -ac_reward=3000000000 -ac_supply=120000000 -ac_pubkey=039433dc3749aece1bd568f374a45da3b0bc6856990d7da3cd175399577940a775 -ac_perc=77777 -ac_blocktime=600 -addnode=5.9.102.210 &

Author: Timo#5756
Content: Yeah testnet is fine. Okay, how does my node get selected to serve someone with data?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you are not understanding

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: ALL nodes get all data and validate all blocks

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: all blocks must have valid data to be accepted by the network

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: like bitcoin validates every tx from genesis

Author: Timo#5756
Content: What happens if 9 nodes say X and my nodes say Y and I try to finalize the block just like the others?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there is a +/- 1% tolerance relative to local prices

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if a block that comes in exceeds that, it is rejected

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: very similar to how timestamps are handled

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: in fact , almost identical

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if a timestamp from the future comes in, it is rejected (if > 60 seconds in KMD)

Author: Timo#5756
Content:
Okay, so I can falsify the value by 0.99%?
9 nodes say price is 10.0$ and my node says it's 10.0111$. What happens at block finalization?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if a price >1% away from local price comes in, it is rejected

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: only one miner mines the block, right?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: doesnt matter what other nodes say, it is not a vote

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is a consensus rule

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is not aggregating

Author: Timo#5756
Content: Why doesn't it matter? If I am the fastest to mine that block and put in my wrong data, who or what is stopping me from that?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: nobody stops you, now you go onto your own fork

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: when the first honest miner mines a valid block the network will accept that one

Author: Timo#5756
Content:
Yeah but my block is valid. I managed to finalize the block the fastest and can put data into it. How could someone else check that the data is false?
If the other 9 nodes say something different, there is an instant fork?

Author: Timo#5756
Content: So it's democratic? Like with hashpower, but just with plain data I put into the block?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it isnt valid if it fails the "are all the prices valid" test
